sites.name: Oia Village Sunset Viewing
sites.description: World-famous village known for its stunning sunsets over the caldera, whitewashed houses, blue-domed churches, and narrow winding paths. Offers breathtaking panoramic views.
sites.seasonal_notes: Extremely crowded during sunset, especially in peak season (July/August). Best photo spots are claimed early.
sites.booking_tips: Explore the village on foot. Arrive at least 1-2 hours before sunset to find a good viewing spot (e.g., near the Byzantine Castle ruins). Alternatively, book a restaurant with a view.

sites.name: Fira (Thira) Town Exploration
sites.description: The vibrant capital of Santorini, perched on the caldera edge. Offers stunning views, museums (Museum of Prehistoric Thera, Archaeological Museum), shops, restaurants, and nightlife. Access to the old port via cable car or steps.
sites.seasonal_notes: Main transportation hub. Can be very busy, especially when cruise ships are in port.
sites.booking_tips: Allow ample time to wander the alleys. Visit museums early. Consider the Fira to Oia hike for incredible views.

sites.name: Akrotiri Archaeological Site
sites.description: A remarkably well-preserved Minoan Bronze Age settlement buried by the Theran volcanic eruption (~1627 BC). Often called the 'Minoan Pompeii,' it features multi-story buildings, frescoes, pottery, and advanced drainage systems under a protective bioclimatic roof.
sites.seasonal_notes: Covered site provides shade. Open year-round, check seasonal hours.
sites.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online or at the entrance. Consider hiring a guide for deeper insights. Allow 1.5-2 hours. Combine with Red Beach nearby.

sites.name: Red Beach (Kokkini Paralia)
sites.description: A unique and dramatic beach characterized by its towering red volcanic cliffs and reddish-black sand. Popular for its striking scenery and snorkeling.
sites.seasonal_notes: Access path can be prone to rockfalls (heed warning signs). Can get very crowded. Water is clear.
sites.booking_tips: Accessible via a short, sometimes rough, path from the parking area or by boat from Akrotiri/Perissa. Limited facilities. Combine with Akrotiri visit.

sites.name: Kamari Beach
sites.description: A long stretch of black volcanic sand and pebbles, backed by a lively promenade filled with restaurants, bars, and shops. Offers organized facilities, sunbeds, umbrellas, and watersports.
sites.seasonal_notes: Family-friendly. Can get busy in summer. Water clarity is good.
sites.booking_tips: Easily accessible. Plenty of amenities available. Located below Ancient Thera.

sites.name: Perissa & Perivolos Beaches
sites.description: A very long black sand beach that merges into Perivolos further south. Perissa is similar to Kamari, while Perivolos often has a more relaxed, loungey beach bar vibe. Known for its deep blue waters.
sites.seasonal_notes: Popular alternative to Kamari. Watersports and diving centers available.
sites.booking_tips: Easily accessible by bus or car. Wide range of accommodation and dining options.

sites.name: Ancient Thera
sites.description: The ruins of an ancient city located atop the Mesa Vouno mountain ridge, separating Kamari and Perissa. Features remnants from Hellenistic, Roman, and Byzantine periods, including temples, a theatre, agora, and gymnasium. Offers spectacular panoramic views.
sites.seasonal_notes: Exposed site, very hot and windy in summer. Check opening hours as they can be limited.
sites.booking_tips: Access via a winding road from Kamari (car/ATV/taxi) or a hiking trail from Perissa. Wear sturdy shoes and bring water. Allow 1.5-2 hours.

sites.name: Skaros Rock Hike (Imerovigli)
sites.description: A prominent headland near Imerovigli village, once the site of Santorini's most important medieval fortress. Offers a scenic hike down from Imerovigli with stunning caldera views and a small chapel (Theoskepasti) on the far side.
sites.seasonal_notes: Trail involves steps and can be exposed to sun/wind. Best avoided during midday heat.
sites.booking_tips: Start the hike from the chapel Agios Georgios in Imerovigli. Wear good walking shoes. Allow 1-1.5 hours for the round trip.

sites.name: Santo Wines Winery
sites.description: One of Santorini's largest and most popular wineries, perched on the caldera cliffs near Pyrgos village. Offers wine tasting flights (especially Assyrtiko), guided tours, a deli shop, and spectacular sunset views.
sites.seasonal_notes: Can get very crowded, especially around sunset. Offers indoor and outdoor seating.
sites.booking_tips: Booking wine tasting slots online is highly recommended, particularly for sunset times. Allow 1.5-2 hours.

sites.name: Ammoudi Bay
sites.description: A charming small port nestled below Oia, famous for its traditional seafood tavernas right on the water's edge. Also a spot for swimming off the rocks (past the restaurants) and boat tour departures.
sites.seasonal_notes: Very popular dining spot. Can be reached by ~300 steps down from Oia or by road.
sites.booking_tips: Reservations recommended for waterfront tables, especially for dinner/sunset. Consider a taxi back up to Oia unless you enjoy climbing steps after dinner.

sites.name: Pyrgos Village Exploration
sites.description: One of the best-preserved medieval villages on Santorini, located inland on a hilltop. Features traditional Cycladic architecture, narrow winding alleys, churches, and the ruins of a Venetian castle (Kasteli) at its summit, offering panoramic views of the island.
sites.seasonal_notes: Less crowded than Oia or Fira. Offers a more authentic village experience.
sites.booking_tips: Explore on foot. Wear comfortable shoes for the uphill climb to the castle. Several cafes and tavernas offer spots to relax.

sites.name: Museum of Prehistoric Thera (Fira)
sites.description: Located in Fira, this museum houses significant finds from the Akrotiri archaeological site, including stunning frescoes (like the 'Fishermen,' 'Boxing Boys,' and 'Blue Monkeys'), pottery, tools, and the famous golden ibex figurine.
sites.seasonal_notes: Air-conditioned. Essential context before or after visiting Akrotiri.
sites.booking_tips: Allow 1-1.5 hours. Tickets can sometimes be combined with Akrotiri or Ancient Thera.

neighborhoods.name: Fira (Thira)
neighborhoods.character: The vibrant capital and main hub of Santorini, perched dramatically on the edge of the caldera cliff (approx. 260m high). A bustling maze of narrow pathways, whitewashed cubic houses, blue-domed churches, shops, restaurants, bars, and hotels offering stunning caldera views. It's the island's commercial, cultural, and transportation center.

location.description: Located on the central-west side of the island, overlooking the caldera.

history.overview: Became the island's capital in the 19th century, replacing Pyrgos. Developed significantly with trade and later tourism. Suffered major damage in the 1956 earthquake but was rebuilt, retaining much of its character while adapting to modern tourism.
history.significance: The administrative, commercial, and social heart of Santorini, offering the most comprehensive range of services and amenities.
notable_events: Development as a major tourist hub (late 20th C - present)

transit: Main bus hub connecting all parts of the island
Main taxi station
Cable car connection to Old Port (Gialos Skala Firon)
Steep path (Donkey Path) connection to Old Port
Limited vehicle access in central caldera-edge paths, main roads accessible
Highly walkable core, but involves many steps
practical_info.safety: Generally very safe. Watch out for uneven steps and crowds. Standard precautions against pickpocketing in busy areas.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Anytime. Busiest during peak summer (July/Aug) and when cruise ships are in. Spring/Autumn offer pleasant weather and fewer crowds. Evenings are lively.
practical_info.walkability: Core area is highly walkable but steep with many stairs. Can be challenging for those with mobility issues.

best_for: First-time visitors wanting a central base

attractions.name: Museum of Prehistoric Thera
attractions.description: Houses important finds from the Akrotiri excavation, including frescoes and pottery.
attractions.appeal: Understand the island's ancient history before or after visiting Akrotiri.

attractions.name: Caldera Walk
attractions.description: Strolling along the main cliffside path offering continuous, breathtaking views.
attractions.appeal: Experience the iconic Santorini caldera views.

attractions.name: Cable Car / Donkey Path to Old Port
attractions.description: Descend to the Old Port (where tender boats arrive) via cable car or the traditional donkey path.
attractions.appeal: Unique transport methods with dramatic views (Cable Car recommended over donkeys for welfare reasons).

dining.name: Fira Restaurants
dining.known_for: Huge variety from budget gyros to luxury caldera-view dining. Many options along the cliff edge.
dining.atmosphere: Ranges from casual takeaways to highly sophisticated restaurants.

activities.name: Sunset Viewing (from bars/restaurants)
activities.description: Enjoying drinks or dinner while watching the sunset over the caldera (Note: Sun sets behind Thirassia/Oia from Fira).

activities.name: Shopping
activities.description: Browsing the numerous shops along the main paths, especially for jewelry, clothing, and art.

activities.name: Bar Hopping
activities.description: Exploring the many bars and clubs, from relaxed cocktail spots to lively dance clubs.

stay_here_if: You want to be in the center of the action and nightlife
Easy access to buses and taxis is important
You want the widest range of shops and restaurants
You enjoy a bustling, energetic atmosphere
avoid_if: You seek peace and quiet
You dislike crowds and tourist bustle
You prefer easy driving and parking (very difficult in core Fira)
You want a traditional village feel (better options exist)
insider_tips: The main square (Plateia Theotokopoulou) is where locals gather and prices are generally lower than on the caldera edge.
Explore the alleys away from the main caldera path for slightly quieter areas and potentially better value.
For a less obstructed sunset view (compared to Oia), consider bars facing south-west.

neighborhoods.name: Oia
neighborhoods.character: World-renowned village at the northern tip of Santorini, famous for its breathtaking sunsets over the caldera, iconic blue-domed churches, whitewashed cave houses (yposkafa) tumbling down the cliff, upscale hotels, art galleries, and sophisticated atmosphere. Largely pedestrianized core.

location.description: Located on the northwestern tip of the island, approx. 12km from Fira.
landmarks: Iconic Blue Domed Churches (Agios Spyridonas & Anastaseos)

history.overview: A significant maritime trading center in the 19th and early 20th centuries, reflected in its neoclassical 'Captains' Houses'. Severely damaged by the 1956 earthquake, it was rebuilt and gradually transformed into a premier, upscale tourist destination.
history.significance: Globally recognized symbol of Greek island beauty, famed for its sunsets and architecture.
notable_events: Reconstruction and rise as luxury destination (late 20th C - present)

transit: Largely pedestrianized center
Bus connection to Fira (terminus near village entrance)
Taxi access mainly at village entrance/bus square
Parking is extremely limited and challenging near the village
Steep steps down to Ammoudi Bay (road access also possible)
practical_info.safety: Very safe. Main concern is navigating dense crowds, especially around sunset. Steep drops from paths require caution.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Morning for photography with fewer crowds. Late afternoon for the sunset spectacle (expect extreme crowds). Spring/Autumn are ideal.
practical_info.walkability: Excellent within the pedestrian core, but involves many steps, narrow paths, and can be slow due to crowds.

attractions.name: Oia Sunset Viewing (Byzantine Castle)
attractions.description: Gathering at the ruins of the Venetian castle to watch the sun dip into the Aegean Sea.
attractions.appeal: Experience one of the world's most famous sunset views (be prepared for crowds).

attractions.name: Iconic Blue Domes Photo Spot
attractions.description: Finding the classic viewpoint for the three blue domes and bell towers.
attractions.appeal: Capture the quintessential Santorini postcard image.

attractions.name: Ammoudi Bay
attractions.description: Charming fishing port below Oia with waterfront tavernas and swimming spots off the rocks.
attractions.appeal: Enjoy fresh seafood by the water, scenic views up to Oia.

dining.name: Oia Restaurants
dining.known_for: Upscale dining with caldera views, romantic settings, fresh seafood (Ammoudi).
dining.atmosphere: Predominantly sophisticated and scenic, often requiring reservations.

activities.name: Wandering the Marble Path
activities.description: Strolling the main pedestrian street, browsing art galleries, boutiques, and jewelry stores.

activities.name: Photography
activities.description: Capturing the stunning architecture, views, and details of the village, especially in the morning light.

activities.name: Hiking Trail Fira-Oia (End point)
activities.description: Completing the scenic caldera hike that starts in Fira and finishes in Oia.

stay_here_if: You want the ultimate romantic, picturesque Santorini experience
Luxury accommodation with caldera views is a priority
Experiencing the famous sunset directly from your area is key
You enjoy browsing art galleries and high-end boutiques
avoid_if: You are on a tight budget (Oia is generally the most expensive area)
You intensely dislike crowds (sunset time is overwhelming)
You need easy parking or vehicle access
You seek lively nightlife (Fira is better)
insider_tips: Explore Oia early in the morning (before 9 am) to experience its beauty without the crowds.
Don't just stick to the main path; wander the smaller side alleys (respecting private property).
For sunset, consider finding a spot slightly away from the castle ruins or book a restaurant/bar with a view well in advance.
The path down to Ammoudi Bay offers great photo opportunities looking back up at Oia.

neighborhoods.name: Imerovigli
neighborhoods.character: Situated at the highest point of the caldera cliffs between Fira and Oia. Known for its tranquility, luxury hotels often featuring private plunge pools/jacuzzis, and stunning panoramic caldera views, including the sunset. Offers a more serene and upscale atmosphere compared to Fira.

location.description: Located on the caldera edge, just north of Firostefani and south of Oia.

history.overview: Historically significant as the location of Skaros Rock, which housed a major Venetian fortress that served as the island's capital until the 18th century. The fortress was eventually abandoned due to earthquakes. The modern village developed as a quieter, upscale residential and tourist area.
history.significance: Offers arguably the best panoramic views from the highest point of the caldera rim. Location of the historic Skaros fortress.
notable_events: Development as a luxury accommodation hub (late 20th C - present)

transit: Located on the main Fira-Oia bus route
Taxi access available
Parking can be tight but generally easier than Fira/Oia centers
Connected to Fira/Firostefani via the scenic caldera path
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Anytime for views. Sunset is spectacular. Quieter than Fira/Oia year-round.
practical_info.walkability: Excellent along the caldera path. Involves steps. Hike to Skaros Rock requires sturdy footwear.

best_for: Visitors prioritizing views and relaxation over nightlife/shopping

attractions.name: Skaros Rock
attractions.description: Prominent headland, site of a former Venetian fortress, offering a rewarding hike and stunning views.
attractions.appeal: Adventurous hike with historical significance and incredible photo opportunities.

attractions.name: Caldera Views
attractions.description: Enjoying the expansive views from hotels, restaurants, or the public caldera path.
attractions.appeal: Considered by many as the best overall viewpoint on the caldera.

dining.name: Imerovigli Restaurants
dining.known_for: High-quality restaurants, often within hotels, focusing on views and fine dining experiences.
dining.atmosphere: Generally upscale, romantic, and quieter than Fira/Oia.

activities.name: Hiking to Skaros Rock
activities.description: Follow the path down from Imerovigli, around the rock, and potentially to the Chapel of Theoskepasti.

activities.name: Walking the Caldera Path (to Fira/Firostefani or towards Oia)
activities.description: Enjoy the scenic paved pathway along the cliff edge connecting the caldera villages.

stay_here_if: You want the best caldera views in a tranquil setting
Luxury accommodation with privacy is desired
You prefer quiet evenings over bustling nightlife
You plan to hike Skaros Rock or the Fira-Oia path
avoid_if: You are on a strict budget
You want a wide variety of shops, restaurants, and bars within immediate walking distance (Fira is better)
You rely heavily on easy access to nightlife (Fira is better)
insider_tips: The walk from Imerovigli to Firostefani and Fira is relatively easy and incredibly scenic.
Even if not staying here, visit for the views and consider the Skaros Rock hike.
Book restaurants in advance, especially those with prime sunset views, as options are fewer than in Fira/Oia.

neighborhoods.name: Firostefani
neighborhoods.character: A smaller, quieter village seamlessly connecting Fira (to the south) and Imerovigli (to the north) along the caldera path. Offers stunning caldera views, including the famous Three Bells of Fira church viewpoint, with a good selection of hotels and restaurants but a more relaxed pace than Fira.

location.description: Located on the caldera edge, immediately north of Fira.
landmarks: Three Bells of Fira (Catholic Church of the Dormition, blue dome & bell tower viewpoint)

history.overview: Essentially developed as an extension of Fira, offering similar views but traditionally a slightly more residential and quieter area. Its name means 'Crown of Fira'.
history.significance: Provides a balance between the bustle of Fira and the tranquility of Imerovigli, home to one of Santorini's most photographed church views.

transit: Easy walking distance to Fira center (10-15 mins via caldera path)
Located on the main Fira-Oia bus route
Taxi access available
Parking can be challenging but often slightly easier than central Fira.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Anytime. Offers great views without the intense crowds of Fira or Oia's sunset point.
practical_info.walkability: Excellent, especially along the scenic caldera path connecting to Fira and Imerovigli.

known_for: Good selection of hotels and restaurants
best_for: Visitors wanting caldera views and proximity to Fira but less bustle

attractions.name: Three Bells of Fira Viewpoint
attractions.description: Iconic view of the blue-domed Catholic Church of the Dormition with its three bells overlooking the caldera.
attractions.appeal: Capture one of Santorini's most famous and beautiful images.

dining.name: Firostefani Restaurants
dining.known_for: Good quality restaurants with caldera views, often slightly less crowded or expensive than prime Fira spots.

activities.name: Walking the Caldera Path
activities.description: Enjoy the easy, scenic walk south to Fira (10-15 mins) or north to Imerovigli (15-20 mins).

stay_here_if: You want caldera views and easy access to Fira without staying right in the busiest part
A balance of convenience and relative quiet is desired
You plan to do a lot of walking along the caldera path
avoid_if: You seek absolute tranquility (Imerovigli or inland villages might be better)
You want extensive shopping or nightlife options right on your doorstep (Fira is better)
insider_tips: Firostefani offers many of the same views as Fira but often with slightly lower accommodation prices.
The Three Bells viewpoint is accessed from a path above the church.

neighborhoods.name: Pyrgos Kallistis
neighborhoods.character: Beautifully preserved traditional inland village built amphitheatrically on a hill crowned by a Venetian castle (Kasteli). Offers panoramic views of the entire island (not just the caldera). Features winding narrow pathways, traditional Cycladic architecture, blue-domed churches, quiet squares, art galleries, cafes, and tavernas. Highest settlement on the island.

location.description: Located inland in the southern-central part of the island, approx. 7km south of Fira.
landmarks: Church of Eisodion tis Theotokou (main church at entrance)
Prophet Elias Monastery (Profitis Ilias) on nearby mountain peak

history.overview: Served as the island's capital before Fira, particularly during the Venetian era when the Kasteli was built. Retained its traditional character due to its inland location and protection as a historical settlement.
history.significance: One of the best-preserved traditional villages and former capital, offering a glimpse into Santorini's past away from the main caldera crowds. Offers the best panoramic views of the whole island.
notable_events: Designated as a preserved traditional settlement

transit: Accessible by bus from Fira
Parking available at the base of the village (can be limited)
Village core is mainly pedestrian, involving steep climbs and steps
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Anytime. Particularly charming in the morning or late afternoon. Easter celebrations are notable here.
practical_info.walkability: Excellent within the village, but requires navigating steep, winding paths and stairs.

best_for: Visitors seeking authentic Greek village life
Those wanting panoramic island views (not just caldera)
Travelers looking for a quieter base

attractions.name: Pyrgos Kasteli
attractions.description: Exploring the ruins of the Venetian castle at the village summit.
attractions.appeal: Historical exploration and the best panoramic views across Santorini.

attractions.name: Wandering the Village Paths
attractions.description: Getting lost in the maze of narrow, whitewashed alleys leading up to the Kasteli.
attractions.appeal: Discover hidden corners, beautiful architecture, and authentic village charm.

dining.name: Pyrgos Tavernas & Cafes
dining.known_for: Traditional tavernas, charming cafes with views, some well-regarded restaurants (e.g., Metaxy Mas nearby).
dining.atmosphere: Relaxed, authentic dining experiences, some with excellent views.

activities.name: Climbing to the Kasteli
activities.description: Walking up through the village to reach the castle ruins at the top.

activities.name: Visiting Profitis Ilias Monastery (nearby)
activities.description: Driving or hiking to the highest point on the island for spectacular views and a visit to the monastery (limited public access).

stay_here_if: You seek an authentic, traditional village experience
Panoramic island views are more important than direct caldera views
You prefer a quieter base away from the main tourist crowds
You enjoy exploring historic architecture
avoid_if: Direct caldera views from your room are essential
You want easy access to beaches (beach towns are better)
You dislike steep climbs and stairs
You need lively nightlife or extensive shopping
insider_tips: Wear comfortable shoes for exploring the steep paths.
Visit Franco's Cafe near the Kasteli for drinks with amazing panoramic views.
Pyrgos is particularly beautiful during sunset, offering a different perspective than the caldera.

neighborhoods.name: Kamari
neighborhoods.character: A popular, family-friendly beach resort town on the south-east coast of Santorini. Known for its long black volcanic sand/pebble beach, organized amenities (sunbeds, umbrellas, watersports), and a lively beachfront promenade lined with restaurants, cafes, bars, and shops. Located at the foot of Mesa Vouno mountain (site of Ancient Thera).

location.description: Located on the south-east coast of the island, approx. 8km from Fira.
landmarks: Access road to Ancient Thera (from Kamari side)

history.overview: Developed primarily as a tourist resort from the mid-20th century onwards, capitalizing on its long beach. Previously agricultural land.
history.significance: One of Santorini's main beach destinations, offering extensive tourist facilities and a different character to the caldera villages.
notable_events: Development as a major beach resort (mid-late 20th C)

transit: Regular bus service to Fira
Taxi access readily available
Easy road access and relatively ample parking compared to caldera villages
Water taxi connection to Perissa (around Mesa Vouno) in summer
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Summer season (May-October) for beach activities. Can be very quiet off-season.
practical_info.walkability: Excellent along the flat beachfront promenade and within the town.

known_for: Wide range of restaurants, bars, and shops
Proximity to Ancient Thera and airport
best_for: Travelers wanting easier parking and flatter terrain
Budget-conscious travelers (often more affordable than caldera)

attractions.name: Kamari Beach
attractions.description: Several kilometers long beach with unique black volcanic sand and pebbles, clear water.
attractions.appeal: Relaxing, swimming, sunbathing with full amenities.

attractions.name: Ancient Thera (via Kamari access)
attractions.description: Accessing the ruins of the ancient city on Mesa Vouno via the winding road from Kamari.
attractions.appeal: Combining history with stunning views over Kamari and the east coast.

dining.name: Kamari Promenade Restaurants & Bars
dining.known_for: Wide variety of dining options directly on the beach promenade, from casual to more upscale.
dining.atmosphere: Lively, beachfront dining, casual attire acceptable.

activities.name: Beach Relaxation & Watersports
activities.description: Enjoying the sunbeds, swimming, and various watersports available along the beach.

activities.name: Evening Stroll on the Promenade
activities.description: Walking along the pedestrianized beachfront road in the evening, choosing a spot for dinner or drinks.

activities.name: Open Air Cinema
activities.description: Watching a movie under the stars at the charming open-air cinema.

stay_here_if: Being directly on the beach is your top priority
You are traveling with family and want easy amenities
You prefer a classic beach resort atmosphere
You want more affordable accommodation options than the caldera
avoid_if: You want caldera views (none here)
You seek tranquility (promenade can be busy/noisy)
You prioritize exploring traditional villages or historical sites (requires travel)
insider_tips: The southern end of the beach near Mesa Vouno is often slightly quieter.
Wear water shoes as the black sand/pebbles can get extremely hot.
Consider the water taxi to Perissa for a change of scenery.

neighborhoods.name: Perissa & Perivolos
neighborhoods.character: Located adjacent to Kamari but separated by the Mesa Vouno mountain, Perissa and the contiguous Perivolos beach form the longest stretch of black volcanic sand beach on Santorini. Perissa tends to be more budget-friendly and backpacker-oriented with campsites and affordable rooms, while Perivolos (further south) is known for its more upscale, trendy beach clubs and bars with comfortable loungers and music.

location.description: Located on the south-east coast, south of Mesa Vouno mountain.
borders: Agios Georgios beach area (south, extension of Perivolos)
landmarks: Church of Timiou Stavrou (large church in Perissa)

history.overview: Similar to Kamari, developed mainly as a tourist area centered around its extensive beach, attracting a mix of visitors including backpackers and those seeking beach club vibes.
history.significance: Offers the longest and arguably most popular black sand beach experience on Santorini, with distinct zones catering to different tastes (Perissa vs Perivolos).

transit: Regular bus service connecting Perissa/Perivolos to Fira
Taxi access available
Relatively easy road access and parking compared to caldera villages
Water taxi connection to Kamari in summer
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Summer season (May-October) for beach life and beach clubs. Very quiet off-season.
practical_info.walkability: Excellent along the flat beach road connecting Perissa and Perivolos.

known_for: Variety of beach bars (budget to trendy)
Access to hiking trail up Ancient Thera (from Perissa side)
best_for: Beach lovers seeking long sandy stretches
Fans of beach clubs and daytime parties (Perivolos)

attractions.name: Perissa/Perivolos Beach
attractions.description: Expansive black sand beach offering diverse ambiances from relaxed to lively.
attractions.appeal: Ideal for sunbathing, swimming, watersports, and enjoying beach bars.

attractions.name: Ancient Thera (via Perissa access)
attractions.description: Accessing the ancient city via the hiking trail starting from Perissa.
attractions.appeal: Challenging hike rewarded with history and panoramic views.

dining.name: Perissa/Perivolos Beachfront Restaurants & Bars
dining.cuisine: Greek, International, Seafood, Pizza, Snacks, Cocktails
dining.known_for: Huge range from cheap eats and traditional tavernas in Perissa to stylish beach club restaurants in Perivolos.
dining.atmosphere: Casual beach dining to sophisticated lounge vibes.

activities.name: Beach Club Hopping (Perivolos)
activities.description: Spending the day lounging at one of the trendy beach clubs with music, cocktails, and food service.

activities.name: Watersports
activities.description: Engaging in various watersports offered along the beach (jet ski, banana boat, etc.).

activities.name: Hiking to Ancient Thera
activities.description: Undertaking the steep hike from Perissa up Mesa Vouno to the archaeological site.

stay_here_if: You want to be right on a long sandy beach
You enjoy beach clubs and a lively daytime beach scene
You are looking for more budget-friendly accommodation options
You prefer a casual resort atmosphere
avoid_if: Caldera views are essential
You seek peace and quiet (Perivolos beach clubs can be loud)
You prioritize cultural sights and traditional villages (requires travel)
insider_tips: Perivolos generally attracts a slightly older/more affluent crowd than Perissa.
The further south you go along Perivolos towards Agios Georgios, the quieter it tends to become.
Wear water shoes due to the hot black sand.

Exploring villages (Pyrgos, Megalochori, Oia) before peak crowds arrive
Wine tasting at local wineries as vineyards come to life
Witnessing Orthodox Easter celebrations (especially in Pyrgos)

Taking a catamaran cruise around the caldera (daytime or sunset)
Enjoying sunset views from Oia, Imerovigli, Fira, or Akrotiri Lighthouse
Dining at waterfront tavernas (Ammoudi Bay, Vlychada)
autumn: Swimming in the still-warm sea with fewer crowds on beaches
Wine tasting during or after the harvest season
Hiking the caldera path with comfortable temperatures
Enjoying stunning sunsets with clearer skies

Enjoying the local, quiet atmosphere in cafes and tavernas that remain open
Taking scenic drives around the island

fine_dining.name: Selene Restaurant
signature_dishes: Creative interpretations of Santorinian classics (Fava, Tomatokeftedes)
Fine dining tasting menus featuring local ingredients
fine_dining.atmosphere: Elegant and refined, often with caldera views (location may vary), focusing on high gastronomy
fine_dining.booking_tips: Book far in advance, especially for caldera view tables. Ideal for a very special occasion. Check current location (moved from Pyrgos).
fine_dining.local_tips: A pioneering restaurant in elevating Santorinian cuisine. Offers cooking classes and wine tastings. Expect innovative dishes and exceptional service.

fine_dining.name: Lauda Restaurant (Andronis Boutique Hotel)
fine_dining.atmosphere: Luxurious, romantic setting carved into the cliffside in Oia with breathtaking caldera views
fine_dining.booking_tips: Essential to book well ahead for sunset. Specify table preference for views. Located within a luxury hotel.
fine_dining.local_tips: Historically the first restaurant in Oia (est. 1971). Offers an unforgettable fine dining experience with one of the best views on the island.

fine_dining.name: Ambrosia Restaurant
fine_dining.atmosphere: Intimate, candlelit terraces overlooking the Oia caldera, very romantic ambiance
fine_dining.booking_tips: Book early and request a front-row caldera view table. Limited seating.
fine_dining.local_tips: Known for its incredibly romantic setting and classic fine dining dishes. Perfect for couples.

casual_dining.name: Metaxy Mas
signature_dishes: Creative daily specials based on seasonal ingredients
casual_dining.atmosphere: Hidden gem with a charming courtyard and terrace offering panoramic island views (not caldera), rustic and authentic feel
casual_dining.reservation_needed: Highly recommended, often booked out weeks in advance
casual_dining.booking_tips: Book well ahead, especially for dinner. Located outside main tourist hubs, near Exo Gonia/Pyrgos.
casual_dining.local_tips: A favorite among locals and informed tourists for its excellent, authentic food and beautiful setting away from the crowds. Worth the detour.

casual_dining.name: Ammoudi Fish Tavern(s)
signature_dishes: Freshly caught fish grilled or fried (choose from display)
casual_dining.atmosphere: Iconic setting right on the water's edge in Ammoudi Bay below Oia, casual yet vibrant
casual_dining.reservation_needed: Highly recommended, especially for sunset tables at popular spots like Dimitris or Katina
casual_dining.booking_tips: Choose your fish from the day's catch. Be prepared for the steps down/up from Oia or take a taxi. Book specific taverna (e.g., Dimitris Ammoudi Taverna, Sunset Ammoudi by Paraskevas, Taverna Katina).
casual_dining.local_tips: Classic Santorini experience. Very fresh seafood in a picturesque location. Prices can be high, especially for premium fish.

casual_dining.name: To Psaraki
signature_dishes: Fresh fish prepared with modern techniques
casual_dining.atmosphere: Relaxed waterfront taverna overlooking Vlychada marina and unique volcanic cliffs
casual_dining.booking_tips: Located away from main towns, near Vlychada beach and marina. Good stop after exploring the south coast.
casual_dining.local_tips: Known for its fresh ingredients, refined yet simple seafood dishes, and pleasant atmosphere away from the caldera crowds.

casual_dining.name: Candouni (Kantouni)
casual_dining.atmosphere: Cozy, traditional taverna tucked away in a quiet alley in Oia, with a beautiful garden courtyard
casual_dining.booking_tips: Offers a more intimate and traditional dining experience in often-crowded Oia.
casual_dining.local_tips: A long-standing Oia favorite for its authentic food and romantic, slightly hidden location.

street_food.name: Lucky's Souvlaki
street_food.local_tips: Iconic, no-frills souvlaki joint in Fira, famous for its delicious and affordable gyros. Often a queue, moves fast.

street_food.name: Yogi Gyro
street_food.local_tips: Popular spot for a quick, tasty, and budget-friendly meal in the Imerovigli area.

street_food.name: Pitogyros
street_food.local_tips: Well-regarded option for quality souvlaki and gyros in Oia, often busy.

coffee_shops.name: Passaggio
coffee_shops.atmosphere: Modern cafe in Oia with stunning caldera views from its terrace
coffee_shops.local_tips: Great spot for a quality coffee break while enjoying the famous Oia view. Can get busy.

coffee_shops.name: Galini Cafe
coffee_shops.atmosphere: Charming, multi-level cafe in Firostefani offering spectacular caldera views in a relaxed setting
coffee_shops.food_options: Breakfast, brunch, salads, sandwiches, crepes, cakes
coffee_shops.local_tips: Located along the Fira-Oia path in Firostefani. Perfect stop for refreshments with an amazing view, often less crowded than Fira/Oia main spots.

coffee_shops.name: Coffee Island / Grigoris (Chains)
coffee_shops.local_tips: Ubiquitous Greek coffee chains found in Fira and other villages. Good for a quick, consistent, and affordable coffee fix, especially takeaway Freddos.

bars.name: Franco's Bar
bars.atmosphere: Iconic, sophisticated bar in Fira famous for its caldera views, deck chairs, and classical music soundtrack
bars.reservation_needed: Highly recommended for sunset deck chairs
bars.local_tips: A Santorini institution since 1979. Known for its unique atmosphere combining stunning views with classical music. Dress smartly. Drinks are expensive.

bars.name: PK Cocktail Bar (Palia Kameni)
bars.specialty: Panoramic Caldera Views & Extensive Cocktail List
signature_drinks: Wide range of classic and signature cocktails
bars.atmosphere: Stylish bar spread over several terraces in Fira, offering arguably some of the best panoramic sunset views
bars.reservation_needed: Essential for good sunset tables, book ahead
bars.local_tips: Arrive early even with a reservation to secure the best spot. Offers unparalleled views of the caldera and sunset.

bars.name: Santo Wines Winery Terrace
bars.specialty: Santorinian Wine Tasting with Caldera Views
bars.atmosphere: Large, modern winery terrace perched on the caldera edge near Pyrgos, spectacular views, often busy
bars.food_options: Cheese/Meat platters, light snacks pairing with wine
bars.reservation_needed: Highly recommended for sunset tasting slots
bars.local_tips: Very popular spot combining wine tasting with amazing views. Book tasting packages online. Can feel touristy but the view and wine are worth it.

bars.name: Marykay's Bar / Hassapiko
bars.type: Music Bar / Old Butcher Shop Bar
bars.atmosphere: Funky, alternative bar in Oia (Marykay's/Hassapiko) housed in an old butcher shop, often with live rock/jazz music
bars.local_tips: A legendary Oia spot for those seeking something different from the caldera view bars. Known for its character and good music. Check for live music schedule.

food_tours.name: Santorini Wine & Food Tasting Tour
highlights: Visiting 1-2 local wineries for tasting (Assyrtiko, Vinsanto)
Sampling local products like fava, tomatokeftedes, chloro cheese, capers
Learning about Santorini's unique volcanic terroir and agriculture
food_tours.booking_tips: Combines winery visits with local food tasting. Several operators offer variations. Check inclusions (transport, number of wineries, food provided).

cooking_classes.name: Santorinian Cuisine Cooking Class
what_you_learn: Preparing Santorini specialties like Tomatokeftedes (tomato fritters), Fava, Santorinian Salad
Using unique local ingredients (cherry tomatoes, white eggplant, capers)
includes: Hands-on instruction, ingredients, recipes, lunch/dinner with wine
cooking_classes.booking_tips: Offered by restaurants (like Selene), wineries, or dedicated cooking schools. Look for classes emphasizing local products.

markets.name: Local Mini Markets & Grocery Stores
highlights: Finding local products like Santorini cherry tomatoes (fresh or paste), capers, fava beans, chloro cheese (if lucky)
markets.hours: Varies, generally long hours in tourist season
markets.location: Villages throughout the island (Fira, Oia, Pyrgos, Kamari etc.)
markets.local_tips: Santorini doesn't have large central markets like Crete. Smaller shops in villages are the main places to find local produce and products. Selection varies.

markets.name: Winery Shops
highlights: Extensive selection of the winery's own wines (Assyrtiko, Nykteri, Vinsanto)
Often sell local products like capers, tomato paste, sweets
markets.hours: Typically winery opening hours (check specific winery)
markets.location: Various wineries across the island (Santo Wines, Venetsanos, Estate Argyros, Domaine Sigalas etc.)
markets.local_tips: Best place to buy specific wines after tasting. Can often arrange shipping.

key_local_products: Santorini Cherry Tomatoes (Tomataki Santorinis): Intensely flavored, small tomatoes grown with minimal water.
Fava Santorinis: Creamy yellow split pea puree, a PDO product, often served warm with olive oil, onions, capers.
White Eggplant (Melitzana Lefki): Sweet, seedless white eggplant, often fried or made into a salad.
Katsouni: A type of local cucumber with a thicker skin and unique flavor.
Capers & Caper Leaves: Grow wild, used widely in salads and dishes.
Chlorotyri: Fresh, creamy goat cheese, hard to find, sometimes made at home.
Assyrtiko Wine: Santorini's flagship white grape, producing dry white wines with high acidity and minerality.
Vinsanto: Traditional sweet dessert wine made from sun-dried grapes (Assyrtiko, Aidani), aged for years.
dishes_to_try: Tomatokeftedes: Santorini tomato fritters, often with herbs and onion.
Sfougato: Savory crustless pie/omelette, often with zucchini or cheese.
Apochti: Air-dried salted pork loin, similar to prosciutto.
Brandada: Salt cod puree (influence from historical trade).
Rabbit or Lamb cooked in wine sauce.
Melitinia: Sweet cheese pies, typically made for Easter.

activities.name: Hiking the Caldera Path (Fira to Oia)
activities.description: Walk the stunning cliffside path connecting Fira and Oia (approx. 10km). Spring offers pleasant temperatures, fewer crowds than summer, and potentially blooming wildflowers, making it ideal for this iconic hike.
activities.seasonal_notes: Perfect hiking weather before the summer heat sets in. The landscape can be greener than other times.
activities.booking_tips: Wear sturdy shoes, bring water and sunscreen. Start early from Fira. The path is mostly clear but has some uneven sections.

activities.name: Orthodox Easter Celebrations in Pyrgos
activities.description: Experience a unique and atmospheric Easter, especially the Epitaphios procession on Good Friday in the traditional village of Pyrgos. The village is lit up with thousands of small fires in cans along the pathways and rooftops, creating a spectacular sight.
activities.seasonal_notes: Dates vary (typically April/May). Pyrgos offers one of the most famous Easter celebrations in the Cyclades. Expect crowds.
activities.booking_tips: Book accommodation and transport well in advance if visiting during Easter week. Arrive in Pyrgos early on Good Friday evening to find a good vantage point.

activities.name: Explore Akrotiri & Ancient Thera
activities.description: Visit the incredibly preserved prehistoric city of Akrotiri and the ancient hilltop city of Thera (on Mesa Vouno) in comfortable spring temperatures before the summer rush.
activities.seasonal_notes: Ideal weather for exploring these significant archaeological sites without intense heat.
activities.booking_tips: Wear comfortable shoes, especially for Ancient Thera (requires uphill walk/drive). Combine Akrotiri visit with nearby Red Beach.

activities.name: Visit Villages Before Peak Season
activities.description: Wander through the charming alleys of Oia, Pyrgos, Megalochori, or Emporio before the peak summer crowds arrive. Enjoy the architecture, views, and a more relaxed atmosphere.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring offers a chance to experience the beauty of Santorini's villages more peacefully.
activities.booking_tips: Rent a car or use local buses to explore different villages beyond the main caldera hubs.

activities.name: Wine Tasting Season Begins
activities.description: Visit Santorini's unique wineries as they fully open for the season. Learn about the island's volcanic terroir and basket-trained vines, and taste the famous Assyrtiko white wine.
activities.seasonal_notes: Vineyards start showing green growth. Pleasant weather for sitting on winery terraces.
activities.booking_tips: Book tastings in advance, especially for popular wineries like Santo Wines (for the view) or Estate Argyros/Domaine Sigalas (for wine focus). Consider a wine tour.

activities.name: Caldera Catamaran Cruise (Day or Sunset)
activities.description: Sail into the caldera on a catamaran. Tours typically include swimming/snorkeling stops (e.g., near Hot Springs, Red/White Beaches), onboard BBQ/meal, and drinks. Sunset cruises offer spectacular views of Oia and the sun dipping into the sea.
activities.seasonal_notes: Peak season for boat tours, offering warm waters for swimming. Sunset slots are extremely popular.
activities.booking_tips: Book well in advance, especially for sunset cruises. Choose between daytime (more swimming) or sunset (views). Shared or private options available.

activities.name: Beach Time (Kamari, Perissa, Perivolos, Red Beach)
activities.description: Relax, swim, and sunbathe at Santorini's unique volcanic beaches. Choose the organized black sand beaches of Kamari or Perissa/Perivolos (with lively beach bars), or the dramatic scenery of the Red Beach (requires short walk).
activities.seasonal_notes: Warmest sea temperatures. Black sand gets extremely hot - wear sandals/water shoes. Beaches are busiest.
activities.booking_tips: Use local buses or rent an ATV/car. Red Beach access can be tricky/closed due to landslide risk - check locally. Perivolos has popular beach clubs.

activities.name: Sunset Viewing Spectacle
activities.description: Witness the world-famous Santorini sunset. Popular spots include the castle ruins in Oia (extremely crowded), bars/restaurants in Fira/Firostefani/Imerovigli, Santo Wines winery, Akrotiri Lighthouse, or from a sunset cruise.
activities.seasonal_notes: The quintessential Santorini summer experience. Expect large crowds at prime locations, especially Oia.
activities.booking_tips: If choosing Oia castle, arrive hours early. For bars/restaurants/cruises, book well in advance and confirm view quality. Consider less crowded spots like Akrotiri Lighthouse or villages like Pyrgos for different perspectives.

activities.name: Explore Ammoudi Bay
activities.description: Descend the steps (or drive down) from Oia to the charming port of Ammoudi Bay. Enjoy lunch or dinner at the waterfront seafood tavernas, or walk past the restaurants to find swimming spots off the rocks with views of the cliffs.
activities.seasonal_notes: Vibrant atmosphere in summer. Seafood is fresh but can be pricey.
activities.booking_tips: Book tavernas in advance for sunset. Be prepared for the climb back up the steps to Oia (or take a taxi).

activities.name: Open Air Cinema Kamari
activities.description: Enjoy a movie under the stars in a beautiful garden setting at Cine Kamari. Films are typically in English with Greek subtitles.
activities.seasonal_notes: A relaxing and charming evening activity, popular during summer months.
activities.booking_tips: Arrive a bit early to get good seats and enjoy a drink from the bar. Check their website for the film schedule.

activities.name: Wine Tasting & Harvest Season
activities.description: Visit wineries during or just after the grape harvest (August/September). Learn about the Assyrtiko grape and Santorini's unique viticulture. Taste the latest vintages and potentially the sweet Vinsanto.
activities.seasonal_notes: Harvest is a key event. Weather is usually still warm and sunny, perfect for winery visits.
activities.booking_tips: Book winery tours/tastings ahead. Consider visiting different types of wineries (large cooperative like Santo vs. smaller estates like Gavalas or Hatzidakis).

activities.name: Hiking in Cooler Temperatures
activities.description: Hike the Fira-Oia caldera path or explore trails in less crowded areas (e.g., around Pyrgos or Emporio) as the intense summer heat subsides.
activities.seasonal_notes: Pleasant temperatures make autumn ideal for longer walks. Caldera path is less congested than in summer.
activities.booking_tips: Wear appropriate footwear. Bring water, although temperatures are milder. Enjoy the clearer air and views.

activities.name: Swimming in Still-Warm Seas
activities.description: Enjoy the beaches (Kamari, Perissa, etc.) with fewer crowds. The sea often remains warm enough for comfortable swimming well into October.
activities.seasonal_notes: A more relaxed beach experience compared to summer. Some beach facilities may start closing down later in autumn.
activities.booking_tips: Check weather forecasts. Enjoy the extra space on the beaches.

activities.name: Explore Sites & Villages with Fewer Crowds
activities.description: Visit Akrotiri, Ancient Thera, and wander through Oia, Fira, or Pyrgos with significantly fewer tourists than in peak summer, allowing for a more intimate experience.
activities.seasonal_notes: Shoulder season offers a good balance of open amenities and reduced crowds.
activities.booking_tips: Check opening hours for archaeological sites, as they may switch to winter schedules later in autumn.

activities.name: Enjoy Clearer Sunset Views
activities.description: Autumn often brings clearer skies after the summer haze, offering potentially more vibrant and sharp sunset views over the caldera.
activities.seasonal_notes: Less atmospheric haze compared to peak summer. Fewer crowds at popular sunset spots like Oia.
activities.booking_tips: Find your preferred viewpoint (Oia, Imerovigli, Akrotiri Lighthouse) and enjoy the view with more breathing room.

activities.name: Explore Fira & Oia's Quiet Charm
activities.description: Experience the iconic villages of Fira and Oia without the summer crowds. Wander the quiet alleys, enjoy the dramatic caldera views in solitude, and appreciate the architecture peacefully.
activities.seasonal_notes: Many tourist shops, restaurants, and some hotels will be closed. The island feels very different, calm and local.
activities.booking_tips: Check which restaurants/cafes remain open (usually fewer, catering to locals). Enjoy the tranquility.

activities.name: Museum Visits
activities.description: Visit the Museum of Prehistoric Thera in Fira and potentially other smaller museums or galleries that may remain open, enjoying them without queues.
activities.seasonal_notes: A good indoor activity for cooler or potentially rainy days.
activities.booking_tips: Confirm winter opening hours in advance as they are often reduced.

activities.name: Enjoy Local Life in Pyrgos or Emporio
activities.description: Visit traditional inland villages like Pyrgos or Emporio, where local life continues year-round. Enjoy coffee at a local 'kafeneio' or a meal at a taverna that stays open for residents.
activities.seasonal_notes: Offers a more authentic glimpse into Santorinian life outside the main tourist season.
activities.booking_tips: Engage with locals respectfully. Fewer dining options will be available compared to summer.

activities.name: Experience Santorini's Tranquility
activities.description: Embrace the peace and quiet of the low season. Enjoy dramatic winter skies over the caldera, find lower accommodation prices, and experience a more personal side of the island.
activities.seasonal_notes: Weather can be mixed (sunny days, rain, wind). Pack layers. Ferry services are reduced.
activities.booking_tips: Ideal for travelers seeking solitude and a break from tourist crowds. Book accommodation with heating.

activities.name: Hiking (Weather Permitting)
activities.description: On clear winter days, hiking trails like the Fira-Oia path or paths around Pyrgos can be invigorating, offering solitude and starkly beautiful landscapes.
activities.seasonal_notes: Check weather forecasts carefully. Trails can be muddy or slippery after rain. Daylight hours are shorter.
activities.booking_tips: Dress warmly in layers and wear waterproof hiking shoes. Inform someone of your route.

ranges.notes: New Year's Day is a public holiday. Santorini is very quiet, with most tourist facilities closed. Some local tavernas in villages like Fira or Pyrgos might be open, serving traditional Vasilopita. Expect minimal activity.

Winter conditions prevail with average highs around 14°C (57°F) and potential for rain and strong winds. Very few tourists. Epiphany (Jan 6th) involves the Blessing of the Waters ceremony at ports like Fira's Old Port (Gialos) or Ammoudi, weather permitting. This is the off-season; enjoy the dramatic, quiet caldera views.

Mid-January is deep winter. Expect cool temperatures, wind, and rain possibilities. Very few tourist services operate. Ideal for solitude seekers wanting raw, dramatic landscapes. Focus on exploring Fira or Pyrgos, visiting the few open cafes/tavernas, and enjoying the quiet.

Late January remains quiet and cool. Some sunny days are possible but weather can be unpredictable. Limited flights and ferry schedules. A time for peaceful walks (weather permitting), visiting the Prehistoric Thera Museum (check winter hours), and experiencing local life in villages away from the caldera edge.

February continues with cool, often windy weather, similar to January. Tourism remains very low. If Apokries (Greek Carnival) falls in February, you might find small local celebrations or parties, especially in Fira or traditional villages, but it's not a major tourist event here. Almond trees may start to blossom late in the month, hinting at spring. Still primarily a time for quiet contemplation and enjoying the stark beauty of the caldera.

March sees a slow transition towards spring. Weather remains variable with sunny spells, rain, and wind. Temperatures average 16°C (61°F). More businesses start preparing to open for the season, but tourism is still low. Good time for hiking (Fira-Oia path) on clear days without the heat. Wildflowers begin appearing.

March 25th is a national holiday. Expect small local parades, likely in Fira. Some shops and sites may have reduced hours, but it's generally low-key compared to mainland Greece. Weather improving but still unpredictable.

Late March sees slightly warmer weather. If Orthodox Easter is early, preparations begin, especially noticeable in villages like Pyrgos. More hotels and restaurants start opening towards the end of the month, anticipating the start of the tourist season in April.

April marks the start of the tourist season. Weather becomes reliably pleasant, averaging 19°C (66°F). If Orthodox Easter falls in April, Santorini offers unique celebrations, especially the atmospheric Good Friday procession in Pyrgos lit by thousands of lamps. Expect increased prices and visitor numbers around Easter. Wineries, restaurants, and shops are generally open. Ideal for hiking and sightseeing before summer heat.

Late April offers beautiful spring weather, perfect for exploring Akrotiri and Ancient Thera. Wildflowers are abundant. The caldera path hike is stunning. Sea temperatures are still cool for swimming (around 16°C/61°F). Tourism picks up steadily, but it's still less crowded than summer.
May 1st is a public holiday. Locals often celebrate with picnics or outings; some transport disruption possible but tourist services generally operate. Weather is typically excellent, warm and sunny.

May is arguably one of the best months to visit Santorini. Weather is consistently warm and sunny (avg high 23°C/73°F) but not yet intensely hot. Perfect for hiking, sightseeing (Akrotiri, Ancient Thera, villages), and boat trips. Sea temperature warms up (around 19°C/66°F), becoming suitable for swimming for many. Tourism is busy but hasn't reached peak summer levels. Everything is open.

June marks the start of true summer weather. Hot, sunny days (avg high 27°C/81°F) with minimal rain. Ideal for beach activities (Kamari, Perissa/Perivolos) and swimming as the sea warms further (around 22°C/72°F). Caldera boat tours (daytime and sunset) are very popular. Tourism increases significantly; book accommodation and popular tours/restaurants in advance.

Late June continues with hot, sunny weather. All tourist services are in full swing. While the main Ifestia (Volcano) Festival is usually later, preparations or related smaller events might occur. It's peak time for enjoying the beaches, caldera views, sunset cocktails, and outdoor dining. Book everything well in advance.

July is peak summer season. Expect hot, dry weather (avg high 29°C/84°F) and strong Meltemi winds, especially in the afternoons. The island is very crowded, particularly Oia for sunset, Fira, and popular beaches. Sea temperature is ideal for swimming (around 24°C/75°F). Essential to book accommodation, ferries, flights, popular restaurants, and tours far in advance. Prioritize early morning or late evening activities to avoid peak heat and crowds.

August continues peak season conditions: very hot (avg high 29°C/84°F, heatwaves possible), dry, often windy (Meltemi), and extremely crowded. Accommodation prices are at their highest. Sea is warmest (around 25°C/77°F). Focus on beaches, boat trips, and evening activities. Sightseeing best done very early morning.

August 15th is a major national holiday. While many Greeks travel, Santorini remains packed with international tourists. Some smaller local shops might close, but tourist services operate fully. Expect peak crowds everywhere.

Late August remains hot, windy, and crowded. The Ifestia Festival, re-enacting the volcanic eruption with fireworks over the caldera, often happens around this time (check specific date annually). This spectacular event draws huge crowds; book viewing spots (restaurants, bars, boats) extremely far in advance. Otherwise, conditions are similar to early August.

ranges.event: Grape Harvest / International Music Festival (Variable Dates)
ranges.notes: Early September is often considered ideal. Weather remains hot and sunny (avg high 27°C/81°F) but slightly less intense than August. Crowds begin to thin slightly, though still busy. Sea remains very warm (around 24°C/75°F). Grape harvest is underway at wineries. The International Music Festival sometimes takes place in Fira. Excellent time for all activities.

Late September sees pleasant warm weather continuing, though evenings might cool slightly. Crowds noticeably decrease compared to peak summer, making sightseeing more enjoyable. Sea is still warm for swimming. A great time for hiking, wine tasting, and exploring villages. Some chance of occasional rain showers towards the end of the month.

Early October offers pleasant autumn weather (avg high 22°C/72°F) with good sunshine hours. Sea remains swimmable for many (around 22°C/72°F). Tourism levels drop significantly, offering a much quieter experience. Ideal for hiking, exploring archaeological sites (Akrotiri, Ancient Thera) comfortably, and wine tasting. Some seasonal businesses might start closing.

Mid-October continues with mild weather, though chances of rain and wind increase. Still excellent for sightseeing without crowds. Many restaurants and hotels remain open, especially in Fira and Oia, but some beach resorts become very quiet.
October 28th is a national holiday. Expect small local parades/school celebrations, likely in Fira. Most tourist sites remain open but check hours. Ferry schedules might be slightly reduced.

Late October marks the end of the main tourist season. Weather becomes more variable. Many seasonal businesses close down. Flights and ferry services are reduced. Enjoy the quiet atmosphere and lower prices, but be prepared for potential closures and less predictable weather.

November is firmly in the off-season. Expect cooler temperatures (avg high 18°C/64°F), increased rain, and wind. Most tourist-oriented businesses are closed, especially outside Fira. Very few tourists. Ideal for those seeking solitude and experiencing local life. Focus on Fira, Pyrgos, visiting the Prehistoric Thera Museum (check hours), and enjoying cozy local tavernas that remain open. Flights and ferries are significantly reduced.

December brings winter weather (avg high 15°C/59°F) with higher chances of rain and strong winds. The island is very quiet. Some festive decorations may appear in Fira, but celebrations are low-key compared to mainland cities. Very limited tourist services available.

Christmas is primarily a quiet, family-oriented holiday in Santorini. Most places are closed. A few restaurants in Fira might offer festive meals, but options are very limited. Don't expect major public celebrations or markets.
The period between Christmas and New Year remains very quiet. Weather can be cold and wet. Very few facilities open. For visitors seeking extreme tranquility and dramatic winter landscapes.

New Year's Eve is low-key. A few restaurants or bars in Fira might host small events or offer special menus (book ahead if available), but large-scale public celebrations are unlikely. Primarily a time for locals.
